section.title: Link words of time and contrast
section.sectiontitle: There are many words/expressions which allow us to link our ideas and narratives in different ways. To link: *things happening at the same time we can use while, whilst, when, as.
section.text1a: While I was talking to John, it started raining.
section.text2a: As the plane took off, she felt a strange sensation of freedom.
section.sectiontitle2: *things that happen when other longer actions are finishing/have finished. We can use by which time or at which point.
section.text3a: I reached the top of the hill at 6.00, by which time I was exhausted.
section.text4a: The film was reaching its climax, at which point we had to leave.

section.title: Link words of time and contrast
section.sectiontitle: *things that happen immediately after the previous action. We can use hardly + when, or + -ing form, no sooner + than.
section.text1a: I'd hardly started eating when the waiter removed my plate.
section.text2a: On hearing of the crash, he ran straight to the hospital. We had no sooner arrived at the camp than the sun came out.
section.sectiontitle2: *things that contrast with previous information. We can use though, although and even though + verb phrase.
section.text3a: We went by train, though I prefer driving.
section.text4a: Although she couldn't run fast, she was the best footballer in the team.

section.title: Link words of time and contrast
section.sectiontitle: We can use despite and in spite of + noun phrase or -ing form.
section.text1a: In spite of my poor exam results, I still managed to get a good job.
section.text2a: Despite working until 10.00p.m. every night, Jonas never finished his tasks on time.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use adjective/adverb + as/though + subject + verb to add emphasis to the contrast.  Typical examples are much as (I like ...), hard though (we tried).
section.text3a: Much as I love television, even I can't watch for more than three or four hours a day.
section.text4a: Hard though she tried, she just couldn't learn Latin verbs.
